hypothesis: Checkout flow bug disproportionately impacts web platform, reducing its conversion rate and dragging down overall platform conversion rate
causal_history: The product team released a new checkout flow on December 16th. If this new checkout has a bug or UX issue on the web platform specifically, users attempting to complete purchases on web would abandon at higher rates. Since web likely represents a significant portion of traffic, this could explain the 15.8% relative decrease in overall conversion rate starting December 17th.
summary_of_analysis_performed: Iteration 1: Analyzed overall conversion rates by platform (web, iOS, Android) comparing baseline period (Dec 10-16) vs anomaly period (Dec 17-24). Found that web conversion rate remained stable at 5.38% in both periods (0.03% change), while iOS conversion dropped dramatically from 4.89% to 2.17% (-55.51% relative change) and Android dropped from 4.45% to 3.99% (-10.37% relative change). The overall conversion rate drop from 5.01% to 3.97% (15.8% relative decrease matching user's report) was driven by iOS and Android, not web. Iteration 2: Confirmed findings by analyzing conversion rates by platform AND product category. Web remained stable across all four categories (electronics, fashion, home, groceries) with average change of only +0.14%. iOS showed consistent massive drops across all categories averaging -55.53%. Android showed consistent moderate drops averaging -10.57%. This categorical consistency demonstrates that the web platform was completely unaffected by the checkout flow change, while iOS was severely impacted and Android moderately impacted across all product segments.

findings.finding: Web platform conversion rate remained completely stable across both periods
findings.evidence: Web baseline: 5.38% (Dec 10-16, 59,017 sessions), Web anomaly: 5.38% (Dec 17-24, 67,160 sessions). Change: +0.03% relative. Stable across all daily observations and all product categories.

findings.finding: iOS platform experienced a severe conversion rate collapse starting immediately on Dec 17
findings.evidence: iOS baseline: 4.89% (44,502 sessions), iOS anomaly: 2.17% (52,840 sessions). Change: -55.51% relative (-2.71 percentage points). Consistent drop observed across all product categories: electronics -55.54%, fashion -54.64%, home -56.33%, groceries -55.60%.

findings.finding: Android platform experienced a moderate conversion rate decline
findings.evidence: Android baseline: 4.45% (30,014 sessions), Android anomaly: 3.99% (35,015 sessions). Change: -10.37% relative (-0.46 percentage points). Consistent drop observed across all product categories: electronics -9.67%, fashion -12.62%, home -9.00%, groceries -10.78%.

findings.finding: The overall conversion rate decline was driven by iOS and Android, not web
findings.evidence: Overall conversion: 5.01% (baseline) â†’ 3.97% (anomaly), representing a 15.8% relative drop matching the user's reported 3.8% to 3.2% decline. Web contributed 44.2% of baseline sessions but maintained stable conversion. iOS contributed 33.3% of baseline sessions but dropped 55.51%. Android contributed 22.5% of baseline sessions and dropped 10.37%. The weighted impact of iOS's severe drop and Android's moderate drop explains the overall decline.

findings.finding: The checkout flow issue, if it exists, affects mobile platforms (iOS/Android) disproportionately, not web
findings.evidence: The hypothesis predicted web would be disproportionately impacted. The actual data shows the opposite: web was not impacted at all (0.03% change), iOS was devastated (-55.51% change), and Android was moderately impacted (-10.37% change). The pattern is consistent and systematic across all product categories, indicating a platform-specific technical issue rather than a product category issue.
